issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car
Atlas drifting while seated in car
Atlas drifting while seated in car
Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
I plotted out atlas' ground truth while seated in drc vehicle and with laser spinning, [see plot here](https://www.dropbox.com/s/ck0jnekp80amxec/atlas_seated_plot.png). I see a small drift in x but not nearly as high as 9cm over 30sec. 

This is what I did: 

- teleport atlas to enter car

- set atlas to nominal mode

- set spindle speed to 2
content.html:
I plotted out atlas' ground truth while seated in drc vehicle and with laser spinning, see plot here. I see a small drift in x but not nearly as high as 9cm over 30sec.

This is what I did:

  • teleport atlas to enter car

  • set atlas to nominal mode

  • set spindle speed to 2

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Hi Twan,

If this is a new phenomenon, the primary suspect might be [gazebo pull request #579](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/579/apply-gazebo-extensions-to-all-collisions/diff) that was merged into [gazebo 1.8.4](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Change_log#Gazebo_1.8.4_.282013-06-03.29).  This patch extends each link's SDF friction coefficient to all of its collision bodies.  Before this bug fix, only one collision body in a link has the right friction coefficient, while the rest of them defaulted to `std::numeric_limits<float>::max()`.  Can you confirm this is new since updating to drcsim 1.8.5?

Also, if available, please post a snapshot of

~~~
rostopic echo /atlas/atlas_state
~~~

of the robot in its seating pose, so I can test putting the robot in a similar pose with PID control to benchmark drift.


Possible solutions:

* increase [uleg](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/b36170c2460b645c420a8e65c0f92139bf845990/ros/atlas_description/urdf/atlas.gazebo?at=default#cl-154) and [pelvis](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/b36170c2460b645c420a8e65c0f92139bf845990/ros/atlas_description/urdf/atlas.gazebo?at=default#cl-166) collision friction coefficients,
* modify [mud seat parameters](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/b36170c2460b645c420a8e65c0f92139bf845990/gazebo_models/environments/mud_atlas/model.sdf?at=default#cl-96).


Thanks,
John
content.html:
Hi Twan,

If this is a new phenomenon, the primary suspect might be gazebo pull request #579 that was merged into gazebo 1.8.4. This patch extends each link's SDF friction coefficient to all of its collision bodies. Before this bug fix, only one collision body in a link has the right friction coefficient, while the rest of them defaulted to std::numeric_limits<float>::max(). Can you confirm this is new since updating to drcsim 1.8.5?

Also, if available, please post a snapshot of

rostopic echo /atlas/atlas_state

of the robot in its seating pose, so I can test putting the robot in a similar pose with PID control to benchmark drift.

Possible solutions:

  • increase uleg and pelvis collision friction coefficients,
  • modify mud seat parameters.

Thanks, John

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
John,

For some reason the rostopic /atlas/atlas_state is not being published. We have cheats enabled (we know this because other hidden topics are visible) but the only topic published under /atlas is /apply_pelvis_force. We are working on reverting and testing gazebo 1.8.3 now.
content.html:
John,

For some reason the rostopic /atlas/atlas_state is not being published. We have cheats enabled (we know this because other hidden topics are visible) but the only topic published under /atlas is /apply_pelvis_force. We are working on reverting and testing gazebo 1.8.3 now.

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Nathan,

Missing `/atlas/*` topics implies AtlasPlugin is unable to load and start correctly.  You might be able to see why under:

~~~
~/.ros/log/[lastest log directory]/gazebo-2-stdout.log
~~~
content.html:
Nathan,

Missing /atlas/* topics implies AtlasPlugin is unable to load and start correctly. You might be able to see why under:

~/.ros/log/[lastest log directory]/gazebo-2-stdout.log

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car
Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Just for reference, running from deb installs of gazebo 1.8.5 and drcsim 2.6.4:

~~~
roslaunch atlas_utils vrc_task_2.launch
rostopic pub --once /drc_world/robot_enter_car geometry_msgs/Pose '{position: { x: -0.02, z: -0.12 }}'
rostopic pub --once /atlas/mode std_msgs/String -- nominal
~~~

and plotting `/ground_truth_odom` for the robot to check drift:

![mud seat drift](#!/osrf/drcsim/issue-attachment/320/osrf/drcsim/1370465154.88/320/mud_seat_drift_gazebo_1.8.5.png)

Thanks for helping us out so quickly as always!

- Twan

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw: Another issue that can cause drift while seated is high PID gains.  We found that reducing the PID gains while seated reduced drift for our team.
content.html: Another issue that can cause drift while seated is high PID gains. We found that reducing the PID gains while seated reduced drift for our team.

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
John,

We tested our controller with 1.8.3 and 1.8.5 (again). See attached plots. They look very similar. As a check, we tested the standard PID controller in 1.8.5 and got the same results you had, so the difference is the controller.

I have a hunch that the standard PID controller may be keeping the robot in place only by virtue of the foot contacts. Since our force controller is trying to not exert any forces on the ground with the feet in the runs for which I posted data, we don't get those foot forces keeping the robot in place. 

See the attached screenshot for the contact forces seen when running the standard PID controller. There are contact forces on the thighs that would push the robot forward, but they are countered by the forces that the feet exert on the bottom plate of the chassis.

Any idea what causes those forward-pointing force vectors on the thighs by the way?

Thanks,
Twan
content.html:
John,

We tested our controller with 1.8.3 and 1.8.5 (again). See attached plots. They look very similar. As a check, we tested the standard PID controller in 1.8.5 and got the same results you had, so the difference is the controller.

I have a hunch that the standard PID controller may be keeping the robot in place only by virtue of the foot contacts. Since our force controller is trying to not exert any forces on the ground with the feet in the runs for which I posted data, we don't get those foot forces keeping the robot in place.

See the attached screenshot for the contact forces seen when running the standard PID controller. There are contact forces on the thighs that would push the robot forward, but they are countered by the forces that the feet exert on the bottom plate of the chassis.

Any idea what causes those forward-pointing force vectors on the thighs by the way?

Thanks, Twan

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Twan,

Regarding the two forward pointing contacts, they are just visualizations.  The contacts between mud-seat and `r_uleg`, `l_uleg` and `pelvis` links are [disabled](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/b36170c2460b645c420a8e65c0f92139bf845990/gazebo_models/environments/mud_atlas/model.sdf?at=default#cl-16).  Only a single fixed joint is formed between mud-seat and `pelvis` and mud-seat and each of the `uleg` links through the [MudPlugin](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/b36170c2460b645c420a8e65c0f92139bf845990/gazebo_models/environments/mud_atlas/model.sdf?at=default#cl-93).  The fixed joints have [zero stiffness](#!/osrf/drcsim/src/b36170c2460b645c420a8e65c0f92139bf845990/gazebo_models/environments/mud_atlas/model.sdf?at=default#cl-95), so should act as pure linear dampers to resist relative motion between mud-seat and robot's `uleg`'s and `pelvis` links.

Per @GoRobotGo's comment, it does sound like the interaction between contact, mud-seat joints and active joint controllers may contribute to the increased drift.  Is reducing PID gains while seated an option for you too?  It feels to be the least invasive surgical option right now.

John
content.html:
Twan,

Regarding the two forward pointing contacts, they are just visualizations. The contacts between mud-seat and r_uleg, l_uleg and pelvis links are disabled. Only a single fixed joint is formed between mud-seat and pelvis and mud-seat and each of the uleg links through the MudPlugin. The fixed joints have zero stiffness, so should act as pure linear dampers to resist relative motion between mud-seat and robot's uleg's and pelvis links.

Per @GoRobotGo's comment, it does sound like the interaction between contact, mud-seat joints and active joint controllers may contribute to the increased drift. Is reducing PID gains while seated an option for you too? It feels to be the least invasive surgical option right now.

John

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car
Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Ah, that explains it then. The problem with purely viscous damping is that a velocity is always required to produce a force, which means that drifting is the only option if a constant force is required.

I thought that there would at least be dry friction between the thighs and pelvis and

```
#!xml

<collision name="seat">
```
at the bottom of the mud box. Is this not the case?

There are ways to work around this, and we've found a strategy that looks somewhat promising yesterday, but (assuming that there is indeed no friction contact) it still seems to me like sitting on a sheet of ice with an oil bath on top is not a very realistic model of sitting in a car, and it is detrimental to our progress.
content.html:
Ah, that explains it then. The problem with purely viscous damping is that a velocity is always required to produce a force, which means that drifting is the only option if a constant force is required.

I thought that there would at least be dry friction between the thighs and pelvis and

<collision name="seat">

at the bottom of the mud box. Is this not the case?

There are ways to work around this, and we've found a strategy that looks somewhat promising yesterday, but (assuming that there is indeed no friction contact) it still seems to me like sitting on a sheet of ice with an oil bath on top is not a very realistic model of sitting in a car, and it is detrimental to our progress.

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw: There is still dry friction between the bottom of the mud box and the thighs and pelvis. The drift comes from noise in our solver and is exacerbated by high PID gains. We're looking into any improvements we can make.
content.html: There is still dry friction between the bottom of the mud box and the thighs and pelvis. The drift comes from noise in our solver and is exacerbated by high PID gains. We're looking into any improvements we can make.

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw: Reducing 'gazebo' PID gains is not possible for us by the way; they are all zero already. Of course we do have feedback in the way we compute effort commands, but the gains are set pretty low there too.
content.html: Reducing 'gazebo' PID gains is not possible for us by the way; they are all zero already. Of course we do have feedback in the way we compute effort commands, but the gains are set pretty low there too.

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Twan,

The drift of atlas standing on seat should be the total drift of the vehicle + atlas, since `/ground_truth_odom` returns the inertial pose of the atlas pelvis.  Did you catch how much drift was between Atlas and the vehicle?

I get similar drift rates when plotting `/ground_truth_odom` with Atlas standing on vehicle seat. But most of the drift is from the vehicle drifting relative to the ground.  Atlas actually appears quite stationary relative to the vehicle.

John
content.html:
Twan,

The drift of atlas standing on seat should be the total drift of the vehicle + atlas, since /ground_truth_odom returns the inertial pose of the atlas pelvis. Did you catch how much drift was between Atlas and the vehicle?

I get similar drift rates when plotting /ground_truth_odom with Atlas standing on vehicle seat. But most of the drift is from the vehicle drifting relative to the ground. Atlas actually appears quite stationary relative to the vehicle.

John

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
Sharon,

Our solution is to stay away from the seat entirely. We just have the pelvis hover over it (and even the mud seat), while balancing using the left foot and left hand, which is holding the roll cage.

Good luck with the competition!

Twan
content.html:
Sharon,

Our solution is to stay away from the seat entirely. We just have the pelvis hover over it (and even the mud seat), while balancing using the left foot and left hand, which is holding the roll cage.

Good luck with the competition!

Twan

issue.title: Atlas drifting while seated in car

content.raw:
I think this issue is strongly related to [gazebo #622](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint)

I think that the reason that the drift was so much higher with our controller than with the PID controller was that we had CFM damping set to zero. John, as you said in
[this comment](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/issue/622/joint-velocities-are-high-when-the-joint#comment-4017148), a way to mitigate contact solution problems is to crank up the CFM damping.
content.html:
I think this issue is strongly related to gazebo #622

I think that the reason that the drift was so much higher with our controller than with the PID controller was that we had CFM damping set to zero. John, as you said in this comment, a way to mitigate contact solution problems is to crank up the CFM damping.
